page.title: 17YORKSHIRE DIALECT - DEWSBURY
page.content: Language experts think that over the next 50 years{dialects will disappear as exposure to television and {computerised voices}increases. A survey was carried out to see if the Yorkshire dialect was dying out in the Dewsbury area. 24{'Yorkshire'}words were chosen at random, some old, some in common use eg.{beck, gill, {maungy,causey and smittled}and then pupils, parents and grand-parents (all born and raised in Yorkshire) were asked to define them. {Results:-}average number of words known: by pupils - 10; by parents - 17; by grand-parents - 21. This provides{strong evidence}that the Yorkshire dialect is dying, a regrettable fact as experts agree it contains words dating back to{Saxon {times}and as such gives us a direct link with our ancestors.
